  621. This trimmer has a very long battery life. The first charge lasted so long that I honestly don't know how long that it lasted.<br />It comes with three different types of blades for different types of trimming, which change in only a few seconds.<br /><br />The only complaint that I have would be directed towards the designers of this unit. It would be perfect if the power button was at the top instead of under the guard height adjustment. It's in kind of an odd position for turning on and off quickly. I invariably hit the height adjustment wheel when I'm trying to turn it off.<br /><br />All-in-all, this is the best trimmer that I've owned. I definitely like the Lithium-ion battery. Ni-cad batteries blow, so this is a major improvement.
  622. After about a month of twice/week use, I am still pretty happy with the trimmer. I like the guard, although the thumb wheel is a little difficult to turn. That isn't a BAD thing- it makes it very hard to accidentally slip to a different setting while in use- it just takes an extra second or two to adjust it. Seems to hold a charge very well, I have yet to recharge it. Lots of little hair clippings seem to get into the area under the changeable blade, but again, doesn't detract from the quality of the device- at least, not yet. Overall, it's not the best designed clipper, but it gets the job done & very nicely. Can't beat the price.
  623. Battery lasts forever. I came from an old school Wahl so I am exited about this being cordless, lighweight and does a nice job of manscaping.
  624. I've been using a Norelco G390 grooming kit for a number of years. I've been happy with it as a beard and mustache trimmer, but the time between charges is getting shorter, it will not work on AC, and the battery is not replaceable. I welcomed the chance to try the Remington MB4040.<br /><br />Unlike my old Norelco, the Remington MB4040 is intended only to trim and groom facial hair. It comes with three heads: beard, goatee, and stubble. There is a grooming comb that can fit over any of the heads.<br /><br />What I like about the Remington MB4040:<br />- The grooming comb slides into a pair of channels and is then adjustable using a thumb wheel.<br />- It is a little bit bigger and noticeably heavier than the Norelco, which makes me think it probably has a more powerful motor and a higher capacity battery.<br />- The heads appear to be well-designed and are nicely finished. Since they are held together with screws, you could probably dissemble them for a through cleaning.<br />-The MB4040 uses a lithium-ion battery, which does not have the memory-effect problems of Nickel Cadmium and is less toxic when it comes time to dispose of it.<br /><br />What I prefer about the Norelco:<br />- The beard grooming guide comb is flexible, which makes it easier to get an even cut while following the contours of my jaw line and chin.<br />- A base was included that has spaces for the trimmer, the five extra heads, the hand comb, and the cleaning brush. I have drawers in my bathroom counter that are deep enough to hold the base with the trimmer standing up, making it easy to keep all the parts together without keeping it on the counter or a shelf.<br /><br />I have a couple of minor issues with the Remington MB4040:<br />- It does not include a travel bag or any other type of container. At the very least, it should come with a small bag or plastic box to hold the two extra trimming heads.<br />- When you open the box, the first impression is that the item has been previously opened and then re-packaged with the inside packaging sloppily stapled back together. In a crowded category of items likely to be given as gifts, the last thing you want is something that looks like it's been sold and returned or maybe even used and returned.<br /><br />On the whole, however, the Remington MB4040 seems to me to be a solid performer that does the job it was designed to do and which should have a fairly long life.
  625. I hadn't tried the stubble beard before and wasn't sure what would be the best tool, but after reading reviews this one was recommended and it works fantastic!

  632. The battery system on this is fantastic. You can go a long time between charges and it feels like it has a ton of power. My only concern is that without a guard in place, the blades can easily &#34;bite&#34; you, for example the top of your lip.
  633. I have a goatee and like to keep it trimmed reasonably short and edged away from my mouth. I was using a barber trimmer and found that the &#34;comb&#34; attachments were either a bit too deep (leaving the beard too long) or a bit too shallow (cutting it too close) with no in-between. With this razor, the ability to ratchet the comb up and down in very small increments using a thumb dial on the body makes this a perfect solution to that problem.<br /><br />I only use the full size blade, so I can't comment on the smaller blade, but the full size cuts adequately, requiring only the occasional second pass to catch a stray hair or two. It's relatively easy to keep clean (see next paragraph) and is small enough to store in the medicine cabinet above the sink so it is ready for instant use.<br /><br />I took away one star for a small (but, to me, important) design glitch. I like to trim/finish my beard away from my mouth (a nod to my wife's not liking to &#34;kiss beard&#34;). In order to do that fine a trim, I need to pull the comb off the head all the way and this isn't particularly smooth or efficient. The comb snaps into the guide and I feel like I'm forcing it to do something it wasn't designed to do by pulling the comb out of the guide. And when I go to replace it in the guide, the design of the barrel of the razor and the placement of the guides doesn't naturally allow this to happen without stopping and perfectly aligning everything. Even if you don't do the fine trimming like I do, you still need to pull the comb off to fully clean the razor so I know I'm not doing anything wrong. It just feels like it is wrong and eventually going to hurt the razor/comb function in some way. I wouldn't call this a show stopper. Just something to be aware of in an otherwise well designed grooming aid.
  634. Very happy with this rechargeable trimmer. Big bang for the buck, quality and its multi purpose exchangeable heads are on par with more expensive units.
  635. This is a bad ass beard trimmer. This thing is powerful and cuts my hairy face with ease. Better than my old Remington which I saved for what reason I have no clue.
  636. I've really liked my Remington MB-200, which has lasted me about four years, until recently the clipper assembly has started coming loose. Not a bad performance lifespan for a $25 trimmer. So, I figure I would treat myself to the \\"upgraded\\" model MB4040 as a replacement... and I couldn't be more sorry for it. First, as others have described, the lowest guard setting is simply not short enough. When I compared, setting the MB4040 guard to #1 (the shortest) it was the equivalent of the MB-200 setting of #3. Second, you can't comfortably use the MB4040 without the clipper guard attached. If you do the clipper teeth snag on your stubble, cut the skin and the bare metal faceplate heats up to nearly burning temperatures. Third, I've gotten very inconsistent trimming length all over my face. I always end up with patches of disproportionately long hairs even after multiple passes. Lastly, albeit the least of problems, the MB4040 is sold within the most annoying product packaging I've ever experienced. You have to literally rip and destroy the box it came in to get it and its accessories out, making a return impossible if you change your mind (as I have). So, in the end I've learned my lesson and am going back to buy a new MB-200 instead, as I should have in the first place.
  637. I was unhappy with the vacuum feature of my previous trimmer and wanted to try something different, so I gave in to the 4.5 stars for this product, my first Remington product ever. Almost from the beginning it has pulled hair when trimming my beard and no matter what I have tried I can't get through a trim without several hairs getting yanked. I am going back to Norelco!
  638. Nice looking. Fits my hand nicely. Easy attachment removal. The adjustable trimmer head is great for me. Hols a decent charge.
  639. This is my first beard trimmer. I liked it very much. It trims the beard perfectly. Battery lasts longer time. Great product!!
  640. I just grew my facial hair back after years of being clean shaven. I figured I would shave it off because of the hassles of keeping it neat. I got this trimmer and love how easy and effective it is. The compliments I've received convinced me this trimmer is the reason I keep the beard.
  641. This is an awesome razor, it is well made and it just feels sturdy compared to some of the other razors I looked at. My husband appreciates the adjustable guard. He doesn't have to switch them out or try to keep up with a bunch of pieces. Once fully charged, he said he can use it for more than week without recharging. With the overall quality and the price, this razor is a great bargain.
  642. Bought this to replace a dying Wahl beard/mustache trimmer. Very happy with this one especialy since the Wahl would no longer hold a charge for more than a day at most. I normally use it without the comb on the end and it is very sharp and does a wonderful job. Glad that it also has a lithium battery, that was one of my main reasons for buying it. I have found the lithium battery technology in my power drills to be long lived and quite impressive. This was a very good buy at a very reasonable price!
  643. It does the trick and saves time. Huge improvement over what I had. Still in initial usage, but seems to be good on battery life
  644. This adjustable clipper is working well, it charges fine and cuts well (i dont have a thick beard, so it cuts fast and clean). When its done i'm happy with the results and I've yet to recharge it since i recieved it a month ago. I clean it using the brush supplied and store it in a ziplock (since I have it in a bathroom and prefer it not rust, a little rice pouch seems to keep it in a dry micro-environnment). the adjusting of the clipper is fine, but when i press it to my face it bends, so you can get uneven cuts. It may be that i'm pressing down too hard but if i dont then i dont get good contact... doesn't bother me as i'd rather keep it on the shorter side.<br /><br />Pro<br />Fast charging, and long life of charge<br />Great cuts, when set at shorter lengths<br /><br />Con<br />The clipper tends to bend at longer lengths. i.e. if you want a longer beard this isnt for you.
  645. For all of you hairy-faced and often misunderstood bearded fellows, behold the power of the MB4040 Lithium Ion Powered Men's Rechargeable Mustache and Beard Trimmer! (With that long name, it has to be perfect right?). This is the facial hair trimmer -and possibly other, non-facial hair trimmer, that would be entirely up to you- you have been looking for<br /><br />The MB4040 is easy to hold in your hand, not too heavy, not too light, ergonomically designed to make your life easier while holding it to go over your face with ease while you make yourself handsome. The 9 different easy to select positions I guess will fit almost anyone needs, from the ZZ Tops out-there to the Indiana Jones. In my case I use it for a 4 setting beard, which I maintain every 3-4 days, and the job is very easy to complete with this machine. The slim body also allows it to go into hard to reach places, and the interchangeable heads for stub, beard and goatee gives you a wide array of possibilities and combinations for different looks. It also charges very fast and the battery last for hours and hours and it is as powerful as Remington claims and trimming is very precise indeed. Seeing its flexibility and wide array of options, I fail to see someone not happy with this trimmer, although there will always be the one that complains that it is missing the moisturizer spreader or that beard-length-self-maintainer button that will be oh! so useful<br /><br />But if you are a regular guy, not insanely picky and on a budget, proud of his beard and ready to fight the naysayers anti-facial hair punks on the streets every day, this is the trimmer for you. Ah, and I haven't tried to maintain \\"The Mighty El Insecto\\" look with this thing. Maybe that's its flaw?
  646. My husband used this to trim his beard about 2-3 times per month for almost a year. It held a charge well, and worked well. But suddenly it wouldn't hold a charge anymore and couldn't even be used plugged in. He threw it away.
  647. Battery Stopped Working after 3 months. A year old and it only goes 30 seconds on a full charge. Takes an hour to do a simple shave.
  648. I have probably owned eight or ten beard trimmers over the past thirty years but this one is heads above all of the others and considering its modest $30.00 price represents a real bargain.<br /><br />I have only had the opportunity to use it a few times but so far I am very impressed. It will most likely prove to be a five star trimmer but it’s just too early to tell.<br /><br />The blade is sharper than I expected, it cuts extremely smoothly, and the motor is very quiet. The comb easily adjusts using the thumb wheel and it locks securely in the selected setting. The Lithium battery charges quickly and should provide a good ling run time.<br /><br />The only thing to note is that when changing the blade it is very difficult to line it up into the correct position and the nylon snaps seem a little flimsy for frequent use. I will only be using the one blade so it is not really an issue for me but if you change blades often it may be something to consider.<br /><br />If I thought that the Lithium battery would hold up under long term storage I would purchase another one as a backup trimmer for use when this one no longer operates properly.
  649. Works well, just takes a bit of getting used to the weird blade angle.
  650. Battery lasts a long time and it may work well to trim beards. It is unsatisfactory for trimming a mustache. The blades do not make a clean sharp line and they do not cut close to the skin where I want to clean up the edges. Others mention blades cutting their faces. Mine is not sharp enough. Maybe Remington responded to those remarks and stopped sharpening the blades as much. In any case I have used this over a month and will attempt to return it to Remington as I believe I have used it too long to return to Amazon.
  651. I definitely love this trimmer !!!! It's slim design is easy to handle and control. It has plenty of power and the adjustable comb gives you the precise length you prefer. I like the trimmer attachment with the smaller teeth that are closer together, it gives you nice straight edges when outlining, of course you must take the comb off. Iv'e had it for almost two months now and would recommend this to a friend.
  652. This item is extremely sharp and easy to use. I also like the fact that it does require being plugged in constantly.
  653. As far as battery life goes, I've never had a shaver quite like this. I charged it the day I got it, and using it once or twice a week in the three months since I haven't had to re-charge it.<br /><br />Using this trimmer without the plastic comb attachment is great. All three blades work wonders on my facial hair, whether it's a beard that's been growing in for three months or a few days' worth of stubble. The goatee trimmer is perfect for edges, and the stubble trimmer is very handy.<br /><br />The only thing holding this trimmer back from a fifth star is the plastic comb attachment. It's a great idea in theory: rather than having a ten detachable plastic combs (one for each length), the one attachment slides over the blades, and a dial on the trimmer moves it up or down to adjust length. Labelling the dial \\"1\\" through \\"9\\" instead of the actual lengths (e.g. \\"1/8\\" or \\"1/4\\") is a bit confusing, but the big issue for me is that using the comb 1-3 times results in an uneven trim. I don't have the \\"pulling\\" problem some other people seem to be having; I just have to go over the same area 10 times to be reasonably sure it's even.<br /><br />So, if beard management is your thing, keep that in mind. But for maintaining stubble or edging your facial hair, this is the best trimmer I've used.
  654. This trimmer works great and does just what I needed in a trimmer. It is very easy to maneuver and trims evenly.
  655. I read almost all of the reviews for almost all of the trimmers out there. I was replacing my Phillips Norelco T980 due to durability issues, so I was looking for a tough trimmer that was easy to use and handle.<br /><br />After a month, I can say that this trimmer is awesome. I like the easy trim-height adjustment with a very solid feedback and nice, solid on/off switch that is not easy to accidently turn off. I like the shape and grip. I love that from my fine head on top, to my coarse hair on my chin, I have never pulled a hair. My only feature wish would be that it had a vacuum function.<br /><br />I must also agree with several of the reviewers that the plastic used for the guide is way too fragile. I am handling it very gently. One word of advice for those having a problem putting the guide back on: notice that there is a bit of an angled \\"target\\" space. Angle it on as you gently push,, and it's perfectly fine.<br /><br />Here's hoping that this is my last trimmer for a long time!

  682. I bought the MB-4040 to replace my old MB-200. I clip my scalp and trim my beard every other day. I've been using it for about three and a half months now, and it's been great. I think I've recharged it one time in that 3.5 months.<br /><br />Pros:<br />* Great battery life.<br />* The power switch is lower-profile than on the MB-200, so it's less likely to turn itself on and drain the battery if you pack it in your luggage.<br />* The adjustment seems to stay put a little bit better than on the MB-200, not that I ever had a problem with the MB-200 slipping.<br />* The clear plastic used in the adjustable spacer looks like it may be more resilient than the that of the MB-200 (a tooth snapped off the MB-200 spacer head when I dropped it in the bathroom).<br /><br />Cons:<br />* The chromed plastic looks cheesy (entirely subjective).<br />* The power button could be recessed to help even more in preventing it from turning on when packed into luggage. Or perhaps a separate travel lock of some sort. It really sucks when you arrive at your destination and realize your trimmer's dead, especially if you were trying to save weight by leaving the power adapter at home!<br /><br />I read some reviews that mentioned snagging and pulling hair. I've never experienced any hair pulling with the MB-4040 or the MB-200. This clips at least as fast an smoothly as the MB-200. Perhaps if you're trimming a very long, curly beard, and you get a hair wrapped around the spacer teeth? I don't see how any similar product could avoid that possibility.

Does it work while charging, yes, and that's awesome. But the blade grabs the hairs on your face and rips them out with such violence, I'm just not sure I can take it anymore. Don't get me wrong, I like it a little rough, but this is insane. That said, it's a much better system than having a dozen different attachments, just roll the wheel and it adjusts quickly.<br /><br />The shaver itself feels as if it's built well, has a quality feel for plastic and the blades snap in nicely and feel secure. It has good power and charges quickly.<br /><br />I'm only using the stubble blade, based on others reviews (thanks) and it shaves great with no cuts even without the guard.
  718. I purchased this because of a fantastic experiences with my ancient Remington beard trimmer. After a week of use, the stubble blade on this unit is falling apart and slicing my face up. My old unit is over a decade old and I have never been sliced by it.
  719. I'm so much disappointed in this product. I used to own a Phillips Norelco which I just loved. This Remington trimmer is just not what I want. It makes my beard look so ugly as many hair stick out after a trim. with the Norelco every trim was so fine and polished. I cant buy that again as Philips discontinued that trimmer.<br />I have ended up with a comb and shears :(<br /><br />I don't care about battery life so much as its not a very important feat in a trimmer which you will mostly use in you bathroom where you have the ability to keep it charged most of the time.
  720. I first purchased the Remington MB4040 and was very excited to give it a try. Sadly, I was disappointed when I tried it and found that it cut a bit too close, nicking my upper neck several times and drawing blood when used without a blade guard. Note: this happened with the stubble blade and the regular blade. One thing I did like about the MB4040 was the mustache/goatee blade, which worked great for trimming my mustache. Also, I didn't like the fact that it can't be powered by the charger, so if your battery runs out, you have to wait for it to get some juice before you can finish your trimming.<br /><br />After returning the MB4040, I purchased the [[ASIN:B00ARF428O Philips Norelco QG3360/42 Multigroom Plus]], as my old trimmer was a Philips and had performed very well for the past 5 years. I was much more pleased with the Philips Norelco than the Remington. At first, I trimmed my whole face and neck down with the regular blade, which did a pretty good job of getting the hairs down pretty short. No nicks or cuts this time, so I was well pleased. A few days later, it was time for some more stubble trimming, and I decided to try the \\"detail trimmer.\\" I found the detail trimmer got the stubble down to just where I like it without any nicks or hair pulling.<br /><br />For me, the Philips won out, but for others the Remington might work better. You just have to give each one a try to see if it works for you.

  725. I trim my beard twice a month. The product seemed well built, had very sharp blades, was quiet and had plenty of battery to complete a trim. Then within about 2 months I noticed battery life was slipping. I do not leave it plugged in between uses so I knew I was not overcharging. In about 4 months the trimmer would not run long enough to finish trimming my beard. Let's do the math, 4 months, trim 2x per month, that's 8 uses of the trimmer and it's already failing. I'm writing this review a year after purchase. I charged it and I tried it again today and it runs for about 20 seconds and dies.<br /><br />So Remington, you build a very nice trimmer and put a crappy battery in it. What does that leave you, a crappy product!!! Consumers if you buy this product you will love it the first couple of months, after that maybe not.<br /><br />UPDATE: 2 years later (Jan 2017)<br />It's been two years now since Remington replaced my trimmer under warranty and I have to say it's working remarkably well. Battery life is no longer an issue and it is still working like it is brand new. The blades are sharp and it trims my beard without tugging, pinching, or hurting in any way. Since Remington resolved the battery issue it's the best trimmer I've ever owned. Thanks for the good service. I'm updating my rating from 1 star to 4 stars, it would have garnered 5 stars had I not had the battery issue on the first unit I received.

  738. Please read the content and understand that it is aimed at the manufacturer rather than the specific device before you flame this review.<br /><br />Let me first thank Amazon for their generous return policy. They're great.<br /><br />I have no idea how well this product works. I never will. If I had seen a picture of the packaging, I wouldn't have ordered it, because it comes in a ridiculously complicated clamshell.<br /><br />Why am I taking this much time to write a negative review? That's the fault of the manufacturer for creating shelf-friendly but user-unfriendly packaging. I never saw it on the shelf, obviously, but I'm sure the package looked great, with the razor and attachments gleaming through plastic clamshell for passers-by to inspect.<br /><br />I open dozens of packages like this every year. I don't have ham fists or mental impairments that keep me from opening them properly. [Insert flame comment here] I go at things carefully, slitting the tape on the sides and top with a pocketknife and then pulling the inside packaging out.<br /><br />Let's describe this particular one. There are two items loosely fit in plastic at the top of the large clamshell. When removing the clamshell from the packaging, these two things fell out onto the table. (The shaver unit itself, and then the plastic cover with the beard comb attached to it.) Turning the package over reveals the power cords and instruction manual underneath. I then ask myself where the other grooming attachments are. Oh - they're still stuck into the top of the package. They're underneath another layer of plastic that is stapled to the inner cardboard shell.<br /><br />Stapled. Interesting. Well, I guess we just pop the staples out since the manufacturer didn't include a staple remover.<br /><br />I use my pocketknife to pry off the staple on the side where the attachments are. The two shaving attachments -- which were more or less stuck to the plastic clamshell that I was trying to pry open -- then fly out of the packaging and onto the floor. Each attachment consists of two blades, one on the front and another on the back that is held in place with a spring and a plastic assembly. Falling to the floor immediately causes them to spring apart, effectively breaking the attachments.<br /><br />Could I try to put these pieces back together? Probably. Should I have to? No. It's the manufacturers fault for creating idiotic packaging that would cause significant damage to necessary parts just by opening the package.<br /><br />What's wrong with a simple box that has a picture of the item on the cover? I can even deal with clamshell plastic provided it can easily be separated to get at the parts.<br /><br />Remington - you and others who do this kind of thing need to understand this.

  753. Remington MB4040 Lithium Ion Powered Men's Rechargeable Mustache and Beard Trimmer<br /><br />The Remington MB4040 looks, feels, and operates like any other cordless trimmer. The main difference is that the MB4040 has a Li-Ion battery pack and these tend to last a LOT longer than the cheaper and more common Nickel Cadmium batteries.<br /><br />The titanium coated blades offer long-lasting sharpness, but many of the other cordless trimmers like the ones from Philips, also feature titanium coated blades. The MB4040 does have interchangeable blades designed for a variety of tasks from trimming beards to maintaining goatees, and trimming hair. The blades are easy to change, but they come fairly well oiled which makes cleaning somewhat messy because the oil attracts the hair shavings and requires some scrubbing with soap.<br /><br />The packaging is total rubbish. The blister pack is stapled to the cardboard, and it made it difficult to remove the trimmer. It does not include any type of storage for the extra blade heads, so I ended up throwing the other blades into a plastic bag.<br /><br />The included adjustable comb is very innovative and easy to use. A few clicks on the thumb wheel will raise or lower the comb. However, the design of the comb allows it to grab my short hair at times. It is too flexible and should have been made more rigid without the open edges that can grab at hairs.<br /><br />The charging LED will shut off to indicate a full charge, which is a nice feature. NiCd cordless trimmers and razors tend to keep charging, while the Li-Ion trimmers/razors usually provide a full charge indicator.<br /><br />Overall: 4/5 stars, there's nothing truly revolutionary about the MB4040. It's a convenient cordless trimmer with a Li-Ion battery pack that allows it to perform better for a longer period of time versus the cheaper NiCd trimmers. I don't like how the comb can grab at my hair, and there's no storage for the extra trimmer heads.
  754. This trimmer has lots of Power, and the charge lasts a LONG time. It doesn't pinch or slow down. Great trimmer!
  755. Once again I read some of the reviews on this trimmer and went for it!<br />I am happy to say I believe it was a good choice. I saw a similiar Remington at WalMart for almost the same price but the WalMart trimmer was lacking some of the heads plus I believe it didn't have the L-Ion battery.<br />Thanks Amazon for handling this particular product.<br />Amazon is great to deal with, and my Prime membership has paid for itself.

I never use the other two heads/cutters.<br /><br />Both my other trimmers had multiple heads and plastic length attachments. They were a pain to carry everywhere. The Norelco seems to have had a more professional cutter, but this one does okay as well. This one has the Li-ion where the Norelco only had Ni-cads. The Wahl was alkaline. The batteries last a lot longer with this Remington. It holds charge longer and I can get several shaves per charge while traveling.<br /><br />I maintain about a 1/2&#34; beard length, give or take. Not a heavy beard either. This shaver works well at about the &#34;7&#34; setting for me - occasionally &#34;6&#34;. As long as I don't go too fast it doesn't pull. I do need to make a lot of passes, but when I'm done, I've always been satisfied with length and even-ness.<br /><br />Self-sharpening & self-oiling are pluses as well. Only reason I didn't go 5 stars is because I lack a lot of experience with other brands. There might be better out there I haven't tried. For the money, I don't think you can wrong by giving this one a shot.

  777. I ordered the Remington MB4040 Trimmer after my old trimmer (not Remington) finally wouldn't hold a charge anymore. I liked the idea of this built-in system instead of the myrid of attachments I previously had for my trimmer. I have used it twice on my beard and had no problems. It cuts quickly without pulling. The adjustment wheel works as I expected and gives a very fine length adjustment for beard, sideburns and around ears. The goatee head allows fine trimming at the lip edges and also cuts quickly and efficiently. I haven't had trouble changing heads, you just have to take the time to do it correctly, which is not hard. It is a little hard to clean all the hair out from under the head because it adheres to the lube oil. I use a can of compressed air but still have to take some time to get the hair out. Again, nothing major and nothing's perfect. I noticed reviewers complained about the Wahl also. Probably, either trimmer works fine. I would purchase again.

It's not a particularly expensive trimmer so you get what you pay for to a certain extent.<br /><br />I recommend the Remington Trimmer. It's a very good value and it does its job quite well.   781. i keep my van dyke trimmed short, and use my normal razor to shape it while i take care of the rest of my face--and so i use the trimmer the way it came out of the box: with a blade that goes the full length of the machine, and with a built-in length guide. the additional blades aren't useful to me and have joined my cluttered drawer of attachments and cords i never use, but keep just in case...<br /><br />something to be aware of: the built-in length guide doesn't really go down to a true stubble. it's not a look that i rock myself, so it doesn't matter to me. if you're looking for a trimmer that you can just buzz over your face without worrying if you'll take off to much, i have my doubts if this critter will do it. i freely admit, however, that i haven't tried to figure out if there's a way to do it or not--because i'm lazy that way ;-)

  787. This trimmer is *guaranteed* to nick you (painfully) in multiple places if you shave against the grain like many guys do. Incidentally, this is the VERY reason why I use a trimmer instead of a shaver most of the time--because I don't like getting nicked, cut, burned, etc. In that regard, this trimmer fails miserably. How in God's name can they allow products like this to reach the consumer? If Remington were a responsible bunch, they'd pull this product from the market immediately. I'm tempted to report it to the CPSC, and I may very well.<br /><br />The problem is the guard; the &#34;teeth&#34; at the tip of of the guard are sharp enough that they actually dig INTO your hair follicle underneath an untrimmed hair, and when this happens, the oscillating blade inevitably meets your skin and blood starts pooling at the site.<br /><br />I've been using a trimmer this way for many years, and never once have I nicked myself as frequently and predictably as I have while using this product. This includes razors and shavers!<br /><br />Remington, your move...

Starting with the mustache, I had a few hairs that were a little too long, so I gently touched the trimmer head to the hairs, and OUCH, there was blood and pain. I don't know what I did wrong. I didn't use any pressure, and I just barely touched the hairs as lightly as I could. Nevertheless, I decided to tempt fate and use the device to detail the sides of my goatee so that they were nice and symmetrical. Regrettably, this resulted in more of the same: pain and bleeding.<br /><br />I called Remington's customer service number, and I explained my experience. I expected that the representative would provide some suggestions, maybe a certain technique of holding the device or something I should do beforehand to prepare my face -- I don't know. Instead, I received a response roughly equivalent to &#34;Yeah, those blades are sharp!&#34;<br /><br />So, back into the box and off to the Amazon returns center it went.

  905. For about two years I owned the Remington MB-300 shaver. The darn thing couldn't hold a battery charge (a common problem if you read the reviews), but darnit, it was the best trimmer I ever owned.<br /><br />After dropping the MB-300 more than a few times, I could no longer piece the trimmer together. It was time to find a replacement.<br /><br />Unfortunately, Remington no longer manufactures the MB-300. Another thing that is unfortunate is that after reading a wealth of reviews on Amazon about available trimmers from the likes of Remington, Wahl and Panasonic, none of them got glowing reviews across the board.<br /><br />I ultimately chose this Remington MB404 for two reasons. First, the battery. It uses a Li-ion battery which is supposed to get better recharge value. Second, based on its price, I figured I was getting something better than those $15 trimmers.<br /><br />I was very disappointed to find upon its arrival that this Remington only works on battery power. The instructions clearly state that it will not operate off AC power while plugged in. I can't totally verify it, as it will run plugged in, but I have a feeling it still may only be operating on battery charge. I can only tell you what the instructions specifically state. This is potentially bad news. You don't want to constantly run this thing on battery while at home. Most would want to save that battery power for travel. After all, there is only so many times you can recharge these batteries before they totally run out of power.<br /><br />The next problem is the multiple clipper attachments. I'm not a fan of this. I would rather just have one clipper attachment that doesn't need to be interchanged. A pop-out trimmer attachment on the side would have been much better. Fortunately, the attachments are very easy to pop in and out.<br /><br />Finally, there's the plastic trim guard. For those that like their goatee and mustache trimmed very close, the guard does not allow the blade to get \\"close enough.\\" I feel as if there could have been one more setting to bring that trimmer closer to the face. It also took me a good 10 minutes to figure out how the trimmer guard fits on the unit. It's a bit of a Rubik's cube predicament, but once you figure it out you are good to go.<br /><br />I suppose the positive things I could say about this trimmer is that it's supposed to be self-sharpening and the fact you don't need to apply oil to it is a big plus.to get \\"close enough.\\" I feel as if there could have been one more setting to bring that trimmer closer to the face. It also took me a good 10 minutes to figure out how the trimmer guard fits on the unit. It's a bit of a Rubik's cube predicament, but once you figure it out you are good to go.<br /><br />I suppose the positive things I could say about this trimmer is that it's supposed to be self-sharpening and the fact you don't need to apply oil to it is a big plus.
  906. i love this Remington MB4040 Lithium Ion Powered Men's Rechargeable Mustache and Beard Trimmer. and i think is one of the best trimmer you can get at its low price
  907. Had a well respected name Wahl trimmer before this one. NO Comparison!<br />The fact that the battery system IS NOT Ni Cad sold me. Look no further for a beard trimmer.<br />Hand wheel depth adjustment is perfect. No qualms in recommending this trimmer at all.

  910. I got this with the intention of using it as a beard trimmer. If you enjoy a closer cut on your beard then this is not for you.   912. Trimmer is pretty sweet, it has a really good system for changing trimmer blades and for changing the head length. Remington brand has done well, the trimmer does exactly what it says it does. It looks great, cuts great, and does not feel cheap at all. The only reason I 4-starred it is because it didn't exceed my expectation/didn't blow my mind, it just does what it's supposed to.<br /><br />(Potential) Con-It's not a precision trimmer, so you will still have stubble on your face if you take the head off and just use the fine-tooth blade. It's not like a straight razor or typical four blade shaver, so it gets its job done, but you still need to use an actual razor if you're looking for a clean shave.
  913. This works great., Much better than my ten year old trimmer did. very easy to use and a very nice cut . easy to adjust length settings
  914. I am finding it really hard to navigate product reviews for beard trimmers, because people seem to have a lot of different needs, and they don't specify what they bought the product for up front.<br /><br />I buy beard trimmers exclusively to replace shaving, because I have sensitive skin, and I don't need to be perfectly clean shaven most of the time. Therefore I don't use any of the attachments or anything, just the bare beard trimmer.<br /><br />My priorities are: as close a trim as possible; high power motor for speed and ease; no cuts, pulling hairs or other irritating events (this is also related to motor power). This product fails pretty much on all three of these counts, for me. The closeness of the trim is average at best, the power is down right bad, significantly worse than wahl products 1/3 of the price. And as for irritation, even with the stubble blade the razor pulls hairs, and has nicked me several times, which is very uncommon in my experience with other products.
  915. Stays charged for much longer than my old trimmer, which ran on NiCad batteries. The LiOn cells don't get a &#34;memory&#34; like the old batteries did. I also find the ergonomic angle of the trimming head to be much better than the classic trimmer style, especially when trimming the back of my neck.
  916. this has been very strange, but i have yet to recharge this trimmer since i purchased it few months ago. and i use it about 2 to 3 times a week for my facial hair and sideburns. i'm starting to wonder if i'll ever need to recharge.<br /><br />i like to try to maintain a natural look with my facial hair, and this trimmer has been great for that. i stopped using my razor all together.
  917. My old one never held a charge like this one. Use it at least once a week and still haven't charged it.
  918. Received as a gift, replacing an MB40, that was a number of years old. The batter finally died.<br /><br />The MB40 was ok. Did the job. I did not realize what i was missing until I used this. The steel cutter is worlds ahead of the foil cutter. Powers through the beard like nothing. Very quiet (compared), and smooth. No pulls at all. Solid feeling. ergonomically very nice. It is easy to adjust, and to switch cutters. I've not had it long enough to comment on durability or battery life, but useability and function are top-notch. I will update this post if there are any issues as time goes on. Recommended.
  919. Before I bought this one I was using a different Remington trimmer from 10 years ago that ran on double A batteries. This trimmer is so much better. It holds a charge very well, the cutting blades move at fairly high speed, and it is powerful enough that it rarely pulls a hair. My only complaint is that the depth guard is a little sharp, but maybe I am just pushing to hard. This works almost as well as my AC powered Wahl hair trimmer.
  920. Unlike other brands I've purchased throughout the years, this one actually holds a strong battery charge for an extended period of time, rather than either having to keep another plugged in or constantly having to recharge it. Sharp and apparently has been reliable for me unlike others. I'd have given it five stars, but still waiting to see how long it stays sharp and holds up. So far, I'm rather pleased with it.
  921. The trimmer stopped holding charge after about two months. Leaving me half-shaved. I tried cleaning & recharging but to no avail. Junk.
  922. This is a great trimmer! It is very powerful and has no problem trimming a thick beard. It's also quiet and charges quickly.
  923. Great product. Keeps my beard looking neat with little effort. Extra shaving heads are a nice plus.<br />This has a nice solid feel to it. I have had this razor about 2 months and have not had to charge it since the initial charge when I first received it.

  927. I bought this for my college-age son for Christmas and it works very well. I has a good, clean cut and seems to hold a charge well. Overall a good purchase and he is pleased with it - but there is room for improvement.

Note that this really sucks when the battery starts to die part way through a trim.<br /><br />I hate to throw the trimmer away, but I'm not sure there's a way to replace the batteries.
  929. pros: works well<br />i just use if for clean up of sideburns and general grooming, not actual beard trimming so the battery lasts forever.<br />so long that i lost the charger and now have to find one online.<br /><br />cons: the adjustment feels a little cheap and that is what broke on my last one.
  930. Solid construction, easy to use for beard and mustache trimming. It does seem to miss more hairs in a single pass than my previous trimmer.
  931. Been through several Mustache & Beard Trimmers & so happy I finally found one that is to my husband's liking! Mission accomplished!
  932. Not having owned this but a few months I haven't had the chance to fully check it out. From the uses I have tried I am very happy that this is a very good instrument and will perform as described.Works great for me!
  933. As a long-time user of beard-trimming devices, I've learned it's the emitted sound that reveals their quality. The tone of this one suggests the internals are precision built and that they will last for a long time. The exchangeable blades are a nice touch, especially at this price point. Battery power and life seem leading edge - I am interested to see how this one ages.<br /><br />All external pieces with which your hand or face make contact have smoothed/rounded edges, unlike a previous trimmer I endured. The only comfort-related gripe, which overall ranks fairly minor, is the positioning of the on/off switch. It sits very low on the handle, making one handed operation awkward. I felt like I was just about to drop the unit when I turned it off.<br /><br />In use, I did experience something that another reviewer mentioned: an occasional single hair that does not get trimmed and the high number of passes required to get consistent length over a specific area. After some examination (and comparison to two other trimmers), I believe the culprit is the wide spacing of the teeth on the adjustable comb. Narrower spacing (as found on the others) forces curlier hairs to straighten. On the Remington, there is room between teeth to allow rogue hairs to remain partially coiled or angled away from the meshing blades. Ooops.<br /><br />So, in short (sorry), extra time is definitely needed for additional passes to achieve truly even beard length - not ideal. It helps to have a fine (..manual..) comb to assist with the straightening duties. And a third hand for the mirror.<br /><br />That adjustable comb is also a bit flimsy. I will be treating it carefully (and making sure to store it at the \\"minimum/No. 1\\" setting) as I don't think the attachment would survive even a single drop onto even a wood (much less tile) floor. Incidentally, setting the adjustment dial to the \\"No. 1\\" setting makes sliding the adjustable comb on or off easier.<br /><br />The too-wide tooth issue is theonly flaw - but a serious one - on an otherwise excellent product. Three stars, then.
  934. When you take off the beard trimmer and try to edge with the blade, this thing will chop you up. I got several deep cuts first time I used it.
  935. For years I've been trimming my beard and moustache with a pair of scissors, most times while still half asleep, sometimes resulting in an uneven trim. It was very time consuming.   976. The battery seems to last a long time between charges, the blade attachments are nicely sized and function fine, and it's a fairly quiet trimmer. My husband has a chin strap style beard and I like for it to be clean cut with a crisp edge and this trimmer works well enough to acheive that.<br /><br />It's not flawless and fantastic like my professional salon quality plug-in trimmer, at times it requires a few extra runs over a spot to get all the hair, and the blades aren't AS precise as I'd like (many of us hairstylists really love a t-blade) this is still a great, inexpensive choice for at-home grooming. I'd definitely recommend it, especially as the price is great and it's fully functional. Feel free to post any questions in the comments below, I'll do my best to answer them.

  1011. Facial hair has been a hobby of mine throughout the years. More than that, I also cut my own hair. So, I've become familiar with a wide variety of cutters and trimmers and suchlike.<br /><br />For the past fair while--well since I got married a few years ago--my hobby has become a bit limited. It's not only my face now. Fortunately, my wife prefers the unshaved look and feel, but not so much the mustache or beard. So, I keep some stubble, never shaving smooth, never letting it long enough to be itchy. That means I trim it about once a week, sometimes more.<br /><br />I've been using an older set of hair clippers, with no guard. That has worked fine, but the battery is pretty old and it's not quite as powerful as it was.<br /><br />I've been looking for a replacement, something that isn't made for hair trimming and isn't as narrow as most beard and mustache trimmers. This fits perfectly.<br /><br />The lithium ion battery keeps the battery charged for a long time, without loss of power when unused. It's quite powerful and cuts well. The beard/mustache trimmer attachment is adjustable. The other parts aren't as much as attachments as different replacement blades which offer different levels of closeness/size. They aren't adjustable.<br /><br />That being said, I thought the stubble attachment was the way to go, only it ended up being a pretty close cut indeed Too close! It looked like I had used a cheap electric razor. The beard attachment actually made a better stubble.
  1012. We purchased this for the ion battery which is working fine so far - we've had it for less than a month, but my husband loves it's power and sharp precision.

  1014. I read all the bad reviews, but I bought this anyway. I figured &#34;How bad can this be?&#34; It's...just as bad as they are saying.<br /><br />I used this for one week (like two shaves) and it worked wonderfully. And then, one day, my cat decided the shaver belonged on the floor. And after a three foot drop, it was. That was the end of my shaver. The adjuster piece broke so that I could no longer adjust the length of the guard.<br /><br />So yes, this is just as bad as everyone says. I don't know that there is anything better available, but that doesn't make this piece of junk any better.
  1015. Everything works as expected. I even dropped it once and it still woeks great. Blades are also in great condition.
  1016. This is an awesome trimmer. I charged it on the first day I got it (December 25th) and it still doesn't need a charge in mid February. The blades work well and I just cant find anything bad to say about it.
  1017. Works perfectly, does excellent job of maintaining the &#34;3-day stubble&#34; I was trying to achieve. My wife does not like beards, but loves the stubble look. This trimmer makes it possible to keep my stubble at the length she likes. Best part is the cost, a true value.
  1018. I don't have a beard any more, so I can't comment on the beard trimming aspect, but I do still have a mustache that needs trimming.<br /><br />I like the way this trimmer works, it did a real nice job thinning out my mustache. Starting from the longest setting and moving in, I never felt I was going to destroy my mustache.<br /><br />I can't explain why it feels cheap to me, maybe too much plastic. But this is about the only complaint I have with it.<br /><br />The trimmer attachment took a few seconds to understand and set, but once I did, that is put it all the way on and use the dial instead of sliding it up and down (like my last trimmer), it was fine.<br /><br />The blade is easy to remove (and reattach).<br /><br />I think this is a nice trimmer.
  1019. My husband has been complaining about how much work it takes to maintain his goatee. I was therefore relieved to give him this shaver for the holidays. His review is as follows:<br /><br />Positives: the battery life. Hubby used it several times before needing to recharge.<br /><br />Travel-friendly: it's cordless and amazingly lightweight, not heavy like his old Remington. He says it's like holding a banana.<br /><br />Blades are easy to remove and switch: right now, hubby is only interested in the detail blade for his goatee but likes how easy it is to pop the other blades in if needed.<br /><br />Easy to dial settings that lock: hubby says the nine settings are a bit much and can't see that much difference between one level and the other. Still, he likes the fact that the wheel locks, ensuring that the trim length is consistent.<br /><br />CONS: hubby says the plastic casing feels cheap. It's lightweight but durability is another matter. Hubby thinks the titanium blades may outlast the shaver itself. However, the item comes with a generous 2 year warranty, which means it should last awhile.<br /><br />Hard to see numbers on the dial: hubby says he had to squint to see the numbers, so they could have been a little bigger.<br /><br />Overall, he says it's a good trimmer and just wishes it felt a little more durable.
  1020. This is a good economical trimmer which is user friendly and not too expensive either. It doesn't have too many fancy gadgets like some of the more expensive devices have nowadays but it does the job and does it pretty well. Recommended.
  1021. The Remington MB4040 Rechargeable Mustache and Beard Trimmer produces a really smooth shave. My husband says that it is better than any other beard shaver he has had. He has had a beard for 32 years, so that is saying something.<br /><br />Having the adjuster built in is a more sturdy design. Most other shavers, the adjuster is a plastic attachment which almost always breaks. Being built it, looks like it will last longer.<br /><br />One way that they could improve the product would be to add a bag to hold all the little pieces that come with it. We had to use one from a previous trimmer.<br /><br />Due to the lack of the bag, I would give the unit a 4.5 rating if it were possible; however, it is too good a trimmer to deserve a four star rating. I recommend it

  1024. I ordered this one in spite of reading some negative reviews. I had assumed that those people were just being picky. After receiving the item, much to my surprise, it appears that I am now one of the picky people. This trimmer for some inexplicable reason just doesn't trim well. Numerous passes over the same area are required, and even then, a few stray whiskers will just sit there and laugh at you.<br /><br />Another problem is that the shortest setting is not short enough for a true short stubble look. I could have lived with a slightly longer beard, but the inconsistent trimming killed that option.<br /><br />I am sending it back to amazon. Thanks amazon for the excellent return policy!

The dial to select a size is nice because it really keeps your setting.<br /><br />I find the plastic comb a little annoying to attach - I can never get the grooves perfectly aligned. It is easy to clean and to switch out the headers with no muss or fuss. I've owned the Wahl for 5 years and the battery continues to recharge, hold a charge and work like new, so I consider it a real plus that the Remington MB4040 has the same type of battery.<br /><br />The MB4040 has nine length settings which give users an excellent range, especially compared to trimmers that only allow one to choose between very short, medium and relatively thick lengths.<br /><br />Highly recommended.

  1113. I too want to jump on the \\"this product is not good at all\\" bandwagon. I have been very impressed by the strength of the MB-200 but it seemed to run out of batteries, and then not hold charge after a few months. Which was a big disappointment- I think it is discontinued but you can still find it on Amazon. I bought the mb4040 thinking this was a successor to the mb-200. This is just not strong at all. Maybe my hair is too thick, I dont know, but I could not get the power needed for a good trim. It just seemed weak and their shortest trim(with attachment) was no where near short enough. All in all a disappointing product. Do not buy.
  1114. I bought this to replace an older Remington model I've had for a few years. Works well, doesn't pull. Haven't had any issues with battery life, and I don't charge it very often. Overall pretty pleased with it. Especially for the price.
  1115. I used a Remington trimmer before and this trimmer pretty much does what I expected it to. The guided lock-in settings are great if you grow long beards or (in my case) want to trim your sideburns to a desired length. I have used the trimmer for one month with no complaints with the blade quality. The real kicker however is the lithium ion battery. I have been using the trimmer for more than two months now, using it about thrice a week, and I HAVE RECHARGED IT ONLY ONCE SO FAR, which was when I received the product and had to charge it completely for the first time ! I haven't recharged it since and the battery still continues to drive the blades fast. I expected the charge to last a while, but this has left me quite surprised. If you, like me, forget to recharge the battery on your trimmer every few days and wake up to find the trimmer not working, this is the product for you.<br /><br />Update 8/22: I lost my charger about 8 months ago and I charged the trimmer about a month before I lost the charger. But I am using the trimmer to this day, without having charged it once over the past 8 months, and continue to use it twice a week. The battery is a beast!!
  1116. Excellent product & safe for use

  1118. Used only once for complete, short haircut and longer, shaped beard trim. Quiet running but it did get hot against my skin. I have used two previous models of this trimmer and this one is by far the best. Yes, I would recommend this to anyone.

  1131. I like this trimmer overall. Especially the dial feature which adjusts the trim length without having to swap attachments. The only issue I have, and it is fairly minor, is if you plan to do detailed trimming, it is not that great. For example, I needed to trim around my teens ears for his ROTC regulation haircut which requires no hair touching the ear. The blade position is not very good for detailed trimming such as this. The smaller blade that is include is also awkward to use for many applications. Had to use my old Norelco which I never really cared for. But it was better designed for detailed trimming. Overall, this is a good trimmer and is powerful and sharp enough and should last a while.
  1132. It is efficient and great for sideburns and goatee. What I like best is that loose hairs do not stick to the handle - I had a pervious trimmer that had a soft rubber type grip that trimmings stuck to like glue.
  1133. I replaced my old Norelco T990 with this Remington since Norelco doesn't make that model anymore (I tried another Norelco model first and it was really bad). I'm glad I did. But, I find that to be the case with all of the beard trimmers especially around the chin. No complaints here. You can't beat it for the price. I even bought a second one.

  1141. I bought this back in January and charged it when I took it out of the box. I have only had to charge it once since then.<br /><br />One of my favorite features is the adjustable guard. It slides off to clean and the blades come out easily (I have some difficulty putting the blades back on since they have a weird angle, but that may be just me.)<br /><br />The guard itself is sturdy, but has some give and has smooth edges. No more feeling like the guard is trying to cut your face off with sharp edges!<br /><br />I had read in another review about it pulling hair. I had no trouble up until the last month or so. It seems to be that if you try to cut off too much (by letting your hair get too long and then trying to take more than 1/3 of an inch or so it does pull some, but that seems to be the only times it is an issue.)

  1144. This is a good trimmer. So far I have not had any problems with it. Seems to hold its charge for several weeks. We shall see how long the battery lasts. My last one (an older model Remington) died after about 2 years of normal use.
  1145. This sucker is nice. It does the job well without being too fiddly. The charge lasts longer than my previous trimmers and the blades do their job nicely. My only complaint is that my old trimmer required a small amount of pressure to get a complete cut when trimming my neck. This trimmer doesn't require that at all. In fact as I've learned the hard way, any pressure at all and you may cut yourself. Just be careful when switching from an older trimmer to this one.
  1146. I purchased this beard trimmer about 3 weeks ago. I read a lot of the reviews on this and similar products and after a while the old adage that &#34;you can't please everybody&#34; seems as true as ever. This is a great trimmer and the battery runs strong and lasts a long time (still working from my initial charge). The battery performance alone makes trimmer worth buying. Add to that the easily adjustable depth gauge (just one so you don't have to manage a collection of 8 different attachments). It runs long and strong, is stylish and does it's job well. Just buy it and unless you are in the &#34;I'll bet I can find something to complain about&#34; crowd, I think you will be as satisfied as I am!
  1147.   1148. I rarely write a review although I purchase often on Amazon. I feel obligated to say something this time. Like some other reviews on this trimmer I had it for a year, actually less, when the battery stopped taking a charge. I tried a couple different methods to see if I could 'restore' the battery's ability to hold a charge, but without success. What is irritating is that And I had followed the user's manual direction and fully discharged the device after six months and recharged for 24 hours. It worked fine afterwards but in less than 12 mos old it no longer holds a charge and operates for only a minute or two before dying. Very disappointed and I assume it is the lithium battery. I previously had Remington NiCad battery trimmer and it lasted for years. Recommend to everyone that you stay away from Remington Lithium models and stick to NiCad versions.
  1149. I received it today, a day earlier than promised. I was a little worried after reading some negative reviews here.   1154. UPDATE: I just finished a quick trim about 20 minutes ago and thought that I should update my review to reflect the additional six months since I began using the trimmer. Really, just a reiteration of what I wrote earlier in the year: hands-down, without question and undeniably the very finest beard trimmer that I have ever owned. In the six or seven months that I've owned this Remington trimmer, I have only charged it once. Trimmers that I've owned in the past – Panasonic, Norelco, etc. – couldn't hold a charge for two weeks, much less six months. I don't know much about Remington but the user manual is great, as is the warranty.<br /><br />I can highly recommend this trimmer to any of my fellow bearded comrades!<br /><br />Forty years ago when I first became serious about growing a beard, I don't believe that there existed anything like a &quot;beard trimmer&quot; – I just used a comb and sharp barber's shears. Some were plug-in models and some were battery operated. Some were better than shears and a comb and, as the years, they got better but not perfect. As my Panasonic trimmer, purchased three years ago, was no longer holding a charge, I came to Amazon and started shopping. When I came across these Remington's, I read quite a few of the reviews and was intrigued by some of the features. I had owned, it seemed, everything but a Remington brand in the past. So I purchased it (I actually purchased two, one as a gift). And it has been far better than any purchased previously. The strength of the motor is better than any battery charged unit that I've used previously, the blades much, much sharper. I've only used it three times in the past two weeks, but the first time was on my beard that hadn't been trimmed in over four months (long story there) and, after getting rid of all that rubbish, actually getting some shape into what was remaining and using the bare blade to get rid of the stubble so that I could partially shave a bit of my neck and cheek so: and all that in the first go with the device. So far, no more charges needed, and I've used it weekly just to keep things in shape.<br /><br />Previous beard trimmers have lasted from one use to three years. I'm betting that this device will outlast that three-year mark. I simply could not be more pleased with the craftsmanship, the ease of use and the results. I hope, however, that I never have to tackle another four-month growth.<br /><br />UPDATE 2:<br /><br />Well - two years and five months have passed and I'm still using this trimmer, every week or so, and it continues to work splendidly. With so many men's grooming devices available now it has become more difficult to choose 'the best' amongst the many. I will not say that this Remington brand is the very finest of the bunch but, for me, it has proven to work very well. Yes, I made the foolish mistake of using the standard blade directly on my skin and, yes, I had four distinct wounds and a bit of blood gushed from each. I am a stubble-faced now, after 40-years of being the full-beard type, and I have to say that the slight beard is so much cooler in the hot summer months. I am still a very pleased user and certainly recommend this trimmer for any man with the slightest facial hair that needs to be tamed.<br /><br />This trimmer continues to be the very best that I have owned. Someone (and I don't know who) slipped another brand's trimmer into my bathroom mirror and I (mistakenly) gave it a whirl: do you wish to see the photos of my toilet-papered face? Well, I'm not posting any!<br /><br />Should I run across any trimmer claimng to be better than this Remington or claiming to be better than any trimmer available, then I would certainly try it. But for the present, I'm sticking with my Remington.t in the first go with the device. So far, no more charges needed, and I've used it weekly just to keep things in shape.<br /><br />Previous beard trimmers have lasted from one use to three years. I'm betting that this device will outlast that three-year mark. I simply could not be more pleased with the craftsmanship, the ease of use and the results. I hope, however, that I never have to tackle another four-month growth.<br /><br />UPDATE 2:<br /><br />Well - two years and five months have passed and I'm still using this trimmer, every week or so, and it continues to work splendidly. With so many men's grooming devices available now it has become more difficult to choose 'the best' amongst the many. I will not say that this Remington brand is the very finest of the bunch but, for me, it has proven to work very well. Yes, I made the foolish mistake of using the standard blade directly on my skin and, yes, I had four distinct wounds and a bit of blood gushed from each. I am a stubble-faced now, after 40-years of being the full-beard type, and I have to say that the slight beard is so much cooler in the hot summer months. I am still a very pleased user and certainly recommend this trimmer for any man with the slightest facial hair that needs to be tamed.<br /><br />This trimmer continues to be the very best that I have owned. Someone (and I don't know who) slipped another brand's trimmer into my bathroom mirror and I (mistakenly) gave it a whirl: do you wish to see the photos of my toilet-papered face? But for the present, I'm sticking with my Remington.

  1176. I purchased this particular brand/model when a previous Remington model (which I had owned and used practically forever) finally failed to keep a charge.   1178. Not sure what happened - but I purchased this a little over a year ago and it has completely died. I did like how it held a charge for a very long time, and I rarely had to charge it, but just recently, I went to re-charge it, and stayed on for about 5 seconds and just dies with the switch still in the \\"on\\" position. Seems like something may have come loose as it works when you hold the blade facing up, but if you flip it upside down, it dies. Un-usable. It is only about $30 though - but not sure it's worth investigating a fix - or just buying a new, better one. UPDATE: So within hours of posting the review above - Roseann at Remington responded to it and asked me to reach out via email or phone to discuss. By the next day, she's sending me a brand new one and a pre-paid shipping label to send back the old one. THAT IS CUSTOMER SERVICE. Thanks, Remington! So yes - battery died after a year - but that's pretty incredible that they're taking care of their customers this way. Well done.

  1189. The only problem with the trimmer , is the plastic adjustment attachment that determines the depth of the cut . It is a little bit cheap and seems to be the first thing that would wear out . It slides down the sides of the trimmer and locks in place , but it needs to be removed for close trims. It will eventually wear out from the constant removal.<br />Other than that , there is no problem with this trimmer . Much stronger and holds a better charge that any other that I have owned in the past.
  1190. This trimmer offers excellent value, with two extra trim heads, sensible design and good battery life. Compared to fancier and more fragile products, this was a real relief. It does not offer easily clogged vacuum features, and thus is a good choice for beards that have gotten too long and need a \\"brush cutter.\\"
  1191. My husband had the same problem others did with the model which preceded this one - after 2 years of use, the battery wouldn't charge. Got him this one hoping the rechargeable lithium battery wouldn't have that issue. Time will tell. I was a little concerned when I read some of the reviews which mentioned how it felt in the hand and pulling of the hair, but he seems 100% satisfied. I held the trimmer, and it seems well balanced, and his beard looked GREAT after he used it - not too short like it sometimes looked with the other model. I think this is a wise purchase, especially if you're looking for a nice Christmas/Hannukah gift for a man in your life! For the money, it's a beautiful item.
  1192. I have this and the older (and cheaper) MB-200. But because I have a short beard, I find myself using the MB-200 more because the plastic guard allows for a closer cut.
  1193. The blades themselves are fine, but the plastic mounts that hold the blades are apparently fragile. The mounts on my beard blade failed after about a year, making the entire blade useless. I visited Remington's website and they wanted $7.99 + tax and $5.99 shipping to get a replacement. $15 is exactly half of the cost that I paid initially for the trimmer itself. No thanks.<br /><br />Sorry Remington. I am cutting my losses and trying someone else.
  1194. The most noticebale first impression offered by the Remington MB4040 beard trimmer is that its motor is powerful enough to provide a very clean cut. The second thing I noticed, though, is that the plastic guard that comes with the trimmer does not have a setting that works well for those wanting to keep their beards relatively short. I found, however, that it is still easy enough to get a smooth, even trim by using the trimmer without the guard in place...so that works out OK.<br /><br />I am particularly pleased that the trimmer is powered by an ion lithium battery that provides up to two-hours of usage time without requiring a recharge. Too, this type of battery does not suffer from a stubborn memory problem and can be \\"topped off\\" whenever the mood strikes without eating into the number of recharges older-style recharables are capable of taking.<br /><br />One warning: the three detachable heads can be taken apart for cleaning or resharpening but they are much harder to get back together than to take apart. I inadvertently disassembled the underside of one of the blades and found it difficult to get the clips high enough to put things back together. In fact, when using one of the other heads as a \\"guide,\\" I managed to push that one out of place, too (Yeah, I know...it's me). But with a little patience, they do go back together so, if this happens to you, don't give up.<br /><br />Love the light weight of the trimmer, not having to use an electric cord, and the specialized uses of the blades included with the trimmer. This is my third trimmer in roughly 10 years, and it will probably be my trimmer-of-choice for a good while to come.
  1195. I bought this to replace my Whal Groomsman. This Remington trimmer cuts much better and the trim height setting works great. I like to keep my beard tight to my face and this does it nicely.
  1196. This was a great trimmer (especially for the price) but after just over a year, it died. The battery seems to have stopped charging. I got very light use (once a week or so) and, frankly, infrequent charging for that reason. But the last few weeks it has gotten weaker and weaker before finally refusing to charge at all.
  1197. I chose this trimmer because it seemed a good balance between quality and low price. I have been quite satisfied. The charge lasts a long time, it cuts nicely, and seems durable.
  1198. I have now used this trimmer for over a year and I am completely satisfied with it. I use it to trim my beard and mustache. The different blades interchange easily and I am amazed by how long the battery lasts. It was a replacement for a previous trimmer with older battery technology and it performs 100% better.
  1199. I needed a trimmer to cut the very short hair on my head, and this was perfect answer. It's a solid trimmer, with accurate, visible adjustment settings and lots of power. I finally charged it after about 5 haircuts, as I felt it was time, but not because it was showing any signs of slowing down. The plastic, multi-length attachment comes on and off easily, so I can adjust for different lengths on the side and back, then take it off to buzz the top of my head. it's wide enough that it doesn't feel like a beard trimmer and does the job quickly and easily. I don't use any of the other accessories except the blade cleaning brush. I had a Remington for many years prior to this and was quite happy with it. The technology has obviously improved and I'm very impressed with this product.
  1200. Did what it was designed to do.
  1201. I got this model for a few reasons: 1) The adjustment wasn't a cheap plastic guard, it uses Li-Ion batteries for long run-time and quick recharge and 3) it was a reasonable price. While I can see the price almost doubled in the two weeks since I bought my trimmer (shame on the seller!). I am very picky when it comes to my electronics and health products, so it says something that I am very pleased with this trimmer.<br /><br />The thing I like the best is that since the guard adjustment is in the trimmer itself, it is extremely sturdy and there is no way it will slip out of your desired guard number. The blades themselves are also very heavy-duty and feel like they are quality made. It powers through beard hair easily and is really easy to clean. I charged it out of the box and have used it twice for my face and armpits with no loss of power. My old shaver couldn't even make it a few minutes.<br /><br />My only warning: I don't think Remington means for you to use the beard blade directly on your face, only with the guard on it. While I don't go for the stubble look, I run the trimmer blades over my face directly instead of actually shaving since my skin is sensitive. Using the &#34;beard trimmer&#34; blade ended up with a few cuts on my face and neck because of the wider-pitched teeth on the blade. A few days later, I re-shaved with the &#34;stubble trimmer&#34; blade and had no problem. It actually cuts pretty close itself. Mark the stubble blade because the only difference between it and the beard blade is how far apart the teeth are on the blade itself. I don't plan on using the beard blade directly on my face again. Ouch!<br /><br />In short, it's a slick device, feels like a quality device, and hopefully will last me a long time. Don't use the &#34;beard trimmer&#34; blade on bare skin or you will end up nicked and bleeding.
  1202. Iuse this shaver not for a beard but for my hair so this review is based upon mostly hair and some facial hiar. I charged this trimmer and it ran for almost 2 months being used 2-3 times a week to cut hair. The only downside is that sometimes the attachments feel flimsy but they will last.
  1203. I got this for my bf and he loves it. He said it trimmed evenly, it felt great on his face, and gave him a smooth trim. He said the attachments were easy to remove too. He said it was a little heavy but nothing he can't handle. I'd recommed this to all the ladies trying to find their guys the perfect gift!

  1214. I really like several features of this trimmer. I find it very easy to adjust the length by rolling the adjustable wheel. The number displayed also lets me know what length I want for different uses.<br /><br />+ Easily Adjustable<br />+ Numbered Length<br />+ Cuts Easily and Does Not Pull Hair<br />+ Great Battery<br /><br />- Curved Shape<br /><br />_Bottom Line_ Yes, I would recommend this trimmer for maintaining simple beard lengths. Other trimmers provide many attachments for other purposes. I do not consider this trimmer multi-purpose. I would recommend looking elsewhere if you want a muli-purpose trimmer. The curved shape feels very strange and it makes it difficult for me to trim with precision. I like everything about this trimmer and would give it 5 stars but I give 4 stars because of the awkward shape.
  1215. Clean cuts, long battery life - have used it once a week (2 minutes per session) for 3 weeks, still going strong, have yet to charge the battery.<br />The adjustable trimmer guard works fine, a little cumbersome reattaching as there are two groves which must be aligned - not a big issue mildly annoying.<br />The trimmer operates at a seemingly high RPM which generates more noise than anticipated - would not operate if someone was sleeping in the next room.<br />Good value for the price.
  1216. This is a really good beard trimmer. I don't keep up with my beard much and don't do fine detailing but want a nice fast cut when I do trim and this does the job.
  1217. I have to admit the product is a very nice trimmer and since it is a Remington I expect it to last a good long time. The extra blade attachments are going to come in handy where others just have one fixed blade and you must either rely on a steady hand and a comb. The adjustable length attachment on the MB4040 is a nice feature as it just take a little dial to change the height so it should be the same each time.<br />Alright, those being the Pro's here come the Con's.<br /><br />I have gone through quite a few beard trimmers generally stepping up in price or brand and have used Remington products in the past; this, however, is the first one I've ever purchased that didn't come with at least a small vile of blade oil. The MB4040 comes with several attachments and yet there is nothing to put them in to store them nor to keep them all separate and protected during travel. It comes with a nice long charging cord but no stand to put the trimmer on and yet in the &#34;warnings&#34; it makes certain to tell you NOT to get it wet, especially while charging, so it's expected that just placing it on the side of the bathroom counter is protection enough. Not everyone that purchases this has a big fancy house with an abundance of bathroom counter space. In this aspect of the Remington design teams infinite wisdom they really dropped the ball. Would it have cost them so much more to create a small tray of some kind so the unit could be stored safely in a drawer or to travel with? At least they could have supplied a plastic cap for the spare blades and a bag to keep everything together.<br />That is my reason for the 4-stars instead of five.
  1218. Bought this because the battery on my last trimmer was dying. Hopefully the lithium battery lasts longer (no memory effect).<br /><br />I use all 3 cutters and they all work great. Stubble trimmer is fantastic for when I don't feel like shaving (most of the time). I use the other cutters for goatee (length 4) and mustache (length 2). Been using it for a month (about twice per week), and I haven't had to go over my facial hair multiple times, nor have I needed to recharge the battery yet.
  1219. Takes way too many passes over my beard to actually trim it. The plastic attachment is way to difficult to put on and it also very bulky when trimming against my beard. Also, this has 9 length settings but on mine length #2 doesn't work.
  1220. This trimmer is acceptable
  1221.   1222. Was great while it lasted but it broke after a few months of use. I purchased it a long time ago but am just now writing the review. I got one for my dad also and his still works so I suppose it's hit or miss. But while it worked it was perfect. The plastic guard thing is more of a gimmick than actually useful though.
  1223. After having a great experience with the previous model, I thought it would be a no-brainier to get the newer one with Lithium Ion batteries, but I was wrong. I chose to ignore the negative ratings that mentioned uneven trimming for close shaves thinking it would be a user error. Unfortunately, I have the same experience (I use setting 1) and am not happy with the trimmer at all. Wish I had bought the older model. Bottom line: If you like close trims don't get this trimmer.
  1224. I use this trimmer to shave down to stubble level, and it's fantastic. I put the stubble blade on, set it to the closest setting, and I get a great, easy shave that leaves me with what looks like 1-2 days of stubble growth. I had a Phillips stubble trimmer before this, and really liked it, but I like this one even better because it's more powerful. I shave once a week, so when I shave my whisker growth is significant, but this trimmer cuts right through, easily. With the Phillips I'd have to go over things several times, but this gets everything the first time. If you're looking for a stubble trimmer I'd definitely give this a try.
  1225. Very good trimmer. Comes with three different attachments (cutter blades) for various situations. I like how they are easily changed by a simple snapping mechanism. It has a powerful motor and the battery life seems to be good. Solid construction; doesn't feel cheap. Great quality. If I had to buy another trimmer, this would be it. Update October 31, 2014. So I have used this trimmer for about 1.5 years. It performed flawlessly until one day, it suddenly wouldn't hold a charge anymore. I could let this thing charge for several days and it would only run maybe 30-60 seconds. Not enough time for me to do what I had to do. So I contacted Panasonic to claim a warranty on this item, because it came with a 2-year Warranty. They promptly sent me a new one and asked me to return the old one via a prepaid mailing label. Received the new one two days ago. Top notch customer service on part of Panasonic!
  1226. I love remington products and had been holding on to my old shaver long past when I should have for fear of not liking anything else. This thing is awesome. The interchangeable heads just pop right on and off without any screwdriver or anything like it kind of looks like.
  1227. Normally I purchase Norelco products, but have always bought Remington trimmers. Finally with a Lithium Ion battery it runs forever before needing a recharge. Full charges takes 8 hours, but a use in the morning and I simply leave it on charge for the day till I return. Great form and function. Trims neatly and precisely, and even tough enough to handle my son's trucker gnarly beard. Great buy and a great value.
